title: How many U.S. states will have a 1.0 or greater effective reproduction number (Rt) for COVID-19 as of 31 August 2020?
preds: As of today, it's 20. Unlikely to exceed 24 tomorrow.
16 as of 29 August, 2 days to go. Looks quite obvious :-)

Still holding steady at 18 states above Rt 1.  Considering the current confusion on the state of, uh, everything, estimate less than 1% chance more than 6 states will report a significant increase in this measure in the next 36 hours.

Considering the confidence band at the Rt projections, states near 1.0 may stay above or below. But likely won't deviate much from the previous past day of daily change rolling averages. Below 24 appears to be a good choice considering the abovementioned. Between 25 and 30 seems entirely plausible but unlikely.

Currently 17 [1]. Nationally, daily positive cases are falling [2]. [1] https://rt.live/
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-positive

What I underestimated so far is the degree to which Rt is influenced by the way that the page
rt.live 
as a source calculates the values - and in my opinion deviates from international standards.
After, say, 18 July 2020 testing volume and thus test results as the underlying figures, which can also be seen on that page under "Details" for every single state, has become less reliable, less steady and thus less meaningful, maybe due to disruptions in the labs, maybe due to scarcity of testing equipment, but maybe also by intention. It seems, however the source page takes the respective daily reports regardless of whether the reported ZERO new cases have been bases on a ZERO volume in tests, or not. This means, the more days there were in a state after 01 August 2020 with zero cases, the higher is the likelihood for this specific state to have an artificially low Rt rate in the most recent weeks, and most likely well below 1.00, even though the number of cases have been on the rise for the past two weeks. This is illogical, so I assume the calculation should have considered reporting days only where the testing volume is non-zero, to avoid any incentive for intentional manipulation and obstruction of testing procedures (for instance, in order to justify school opening, business as usual, travel and leisure etc etc)
If you compare e.g. New Jersey (0.95 as of 26 August 2020) and North Carolina (1.14), then cases in NJ on 13 August 2020 (656 cases from 27,674 tests) have been higher than on 23 July 2020 (242 cases from 18,709 tests), nevertheless Rt decreased over that 3 week-time span from 0.98 to 0.94 which is not explicable solely from time lags and other technicalities. The logic behind Rt is to indicate an accelerated spread, which obviously happened in this time frame. What NJ did experience was a frequent blank out in testing and/or reporting (if the data Rt.live uses are the accurate and official ones...): 
25 July 2020 (no tests, no reported new cases)
28 July 2020 (no tests, no reported new cases)
01 August 2020 (no tests, no reported new cases)
04 August 2020 (no tests, no reported new cases)
09 August 2020 (no tests, no reported new cases)
16 August 2020 (28,803 tests, 13(!) reported new cases)
20 August 2020 (27,495 tests, 100(!) reported new cases, less than a third of previous day's report)
23 August 2020 (no tests, no reported new cases) Before 18 July 2020, there has been only ONE occasion in which figures failed to come in or were illogical, namely on 11 May 2020 (113,486 tests, no reported new cases), so my best guess is that this phenomenon is closely linked to the transfer of control from CDC to HHS around 20 July 2020, and somebody is doctoring the figures now.
Unsurprisingly, the figures look differently for North Carolina, where the number of cases has risen until 18 July 2020 (2,481 cases from 35,169 tests) and are now slightly declining (e.g. 1,729 cases from 21,233 tests on 22 August 2020), and still NC has a Rt rate of 1.14, way above the 1.00 threshold.
The only difference I see is:
North Carolina, as it has been a hot spot for the whole of August, had only one occasion where reported cases and testing volume was ZERO, namely on 12 August 2020. I haven't gone through all of the states' figures but it looks like the currently low number of states with an Rt rate of less than 1.0 are an artifact from the wish list of the current WH administration; my only explanation. However, if testing starts to improve and, most of all, continues from now on without ZERO reporting days, there are many states that may see their Rt rate rising again, just because of a frictionless data flow. I consider every state with a current Rt of 0.95 or higher to be eligible ending up above 1.00, so from today - even in a very short time frame - the number of states could rise from 17 to 30 from my point of view, or even higher to the next bin starting at 31.
The WH's rationale behind doctoring the figures seems clear. It's all owed to campaigning.
When Rt s rise across states, POTUS will argue, that everything was "beautiful" until governors (mainly democrats, allegedly) "messed up the school reopening". Nice try.
Currently 17 states above, and a further 7 within 0.5 . so going all in on 24 or fewer given the time range

18 states currently above Rt 1.0 - a positive trend that has continued for weeks.  Might see a slight bump from recent large gatherings, but coupled with decreased testing and new CDC directive that not all exposed need to be tested - I think it is near certainty that less than 24 states will be above.
Its already deep into bin 1 with 18 states above 1

All in.
Only 18 at or above 1.0, 4 of them at 1.0. Only 6 days to go.

Currently 18. About 7 of those states are bet 1.0 and 1.05, and about 3 states are bet 1.0 and 1.02. 1 state is exactly 1.0. About 13 states are in between 0.95 and 0.99. And about 7 states are either at 0.98 and 0.99. And I say "about" in case of human error.
Rt is very volatile.  The number of states with Rt >0.99 could remain below 25, but a brief spike cannot be ruled out.  With one week to go I'll stay close to the crowd.
Today 20 at or above 1.0. 8 days left (including 2 sundays with traditionally lower numbers). General trend of new cases still downwards.

It is Aug 22 and the current number with an rt >1 is 19 states. There have been no events in the previous week that would trigger a spike that has not been recorded in the next 10 days. While future spikes are possible the timing on 31 Aug is unlikely.
32 below Rt 1.0 today/19 at or above, only 9 days to go. Not safe yet for bin 1, but this looks really good.

Currently 18. About 6 of those states are bet 1.0 and 1.05, and about 3 states are bet 1.0 and 1.02. 3 states are exactly 1.0. About 15 states are in between 0.95 and 0.99. And about 6 states are either at 0.98 and 0.99. And I say "about" in case of human error.
A problem I see is that with so many 0.97's, 0.98's and 0.99's things can change very quickly.

The number of states with Rt >= 1.0 has fallen fast over the past four days, from 31 to 24.  So the crowd has moved down to cover the lowest bracket.  I would note that there are 13 states with Rt between 0.99 and 1.01.  A very small change in Rt can cause a big shift in the number of states that meet the test criterion.  With three weeks remaining, the results could surprise.
30-36 feels reasonable... the question is regarding lag time and accuracy of results.

It was really foolish to go for three different trends simultaneously:
1) This one: going for general number of cases going down (the good old s-curve)
2) Fatality rate: would need many more new cases with few deaths for that, and
3) Positivity rate: would need many tests and few positives.
I bet on all of those, and it was a time-consuming mistake. Best guess for the moment: I´ll win on this one and lose on the others. Ceterum censeo: NO more new Covid-19 questions.

I used the CSV data provided by rt.live to generate my own spreadsheet of "Number of states with Rt > 1 by date" here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQS-FYNmK-xypKJL2Qp0GkpsccfjXZdCbgAo0aNb1MHI3RXCNxEKlZ1mqwc3_8fJGhrqp-xaxUPCA9p/pubhtml Coming in late to this may be an advantage as the last 30 days the day-to-day variance in number of states with Rt > 1 has really flattened out. Average since 7/4 ~ 30.5, max 31, min 27 There are a lot of factors that go into this but just looking over the state graphs at rt.live, government policy seems to play the most significant role. Assuming policy makers are trying to find the right balance of restricting economic activity vs raising Rt (or some proxy for those goals), it looks like we may be zeroing in on some balance people feel comfortable with (all though I understand almost no one _really_ feels "comfortable" with the situation we're in). In the interest of time (I've spent a fair amount on forecasting this weekend ;) ) I'm going to just assume that there is a strong possibility the current trend is maintained and that the most likely case is a value between 25 and 36 with significantly decreasing odds as we move away from those numbers. I will adjust probabilities on the high end lower than the low end simply because I believe people are pretty quick to respond to changes in the numbers these days so the number of states would seem more likely to decrease than increase (again, just my intuition working here). If I'm missing something big, be glad to hear about it!

This question pertains to a snapshot of the Rt values on a single day, August 31.  Every day there is new data which is incorporated into the model, and the value of Rt often changes by as much as 0.05.  Since there are many states with Rt between 0.95 and 1.05 the number of states with Rt>0.99 can jump around, i.e., the signal is obscured by a lot of noise.  So it could be dangerous to put all your chips on one bracket.  The key will be to find the signal in the noise.

14 states below 1.0, 14 more below 1.5. Median1.04. Trend still clearly down.
Number of daily new cases in the US plateaued. Perhaps even in the US the normal pattern will materialize in the next few weeks.

Number of daily new cases in the US seems to have plateaued. Perhaps even in the US the normal pattern will materialize in the next few weeks.

Almost unchanged: today 12 states below 1.0 (would be enough for bin 4), 14 more below 1.5 (all those going down below 1.0 would be enough for bin 2). Median1.04. 36 states below 1.10.
Looks like daily cases in the US really have peaked/plateaued, so in a non-US-setting the trend should lead to about half of the states above and half below 1.0 in the next 38 days to go. 
Only serious problem challenging that theory: their last peak was 3 1/2 months ago and only half as big as the current one. All of Europe and most of Asia got it under control very, very much quicker and better.

Using Rt.live as cited above: Based on 38 states currently above Rt1.0.  2 weeks ago, the trends were remarkably similar to the current one. This is particularly notable compared to the 1 month prior when everyone was out and about.  I feel that in a few weeks time, the number of states above Rt1 will remain fairly consistent.    I add more consideration to less than 36 as multiple states have been hovering just above Rt1 and could easily swing in a small positive direction. I put additional weight (albeit very small) in the less than 30 bin - as the recent push by WH to wear a mask and take seriously may, possibly, have some effect at furthering precautions taken by the public.  This could push the number of states under Rt1 significantly downward (see 2 mos ago for comparison).   I feel it is more likely that the number of states with Rt >/= 1 will increase to above 43 over decreasing to under 30. Overall, I still predict it will remain fairly stable - say between 35-40.
43 states are so far > 1 ; as the cases increases, certain states may take actions but will not fully return to a complete lockdown as we have damaged considerably the economy.

Today 12 states below 1.0 (would be enough for bin 4), 15 more below 1.5 (all those going down below 1.0 would be enough for bin 1). Median down to 1.04. 35 states below 1.10.
Looks like daily cases in the US really have plateaued. 38 days to go. All bins still possible, but the trend seems clear. Feels lonely so hard against the crowd, but sometimes a mans´s gotta do, what a man´s gotta do...

Currently 12 states moving in the right direction ... situation improving. 
Still a long ways off.

Today 12 states below 1.0 (would be enough for bin 4), 13 more below 1.5 (all those going down below 1.0 would be enough for bin 2). Median down to 1.04. 34 states below 1.10.
Looks like daily cases in the US could have plateaued. 38 days to go. All bins still possible.

The overwhelming majority of the states are currently over 1. Restrictions are loosening in most states. People who have spent all spring and summer are getting more and more anxious to get out and restart their life. People will be looking forward to get some vacations in and will attempt to rationalize breaking best practices for the sake of their mental health. All of this is likely to push the rate of new infections to grow. A likely continued growth in cases could tie up testing at an increased rate, and if/when that happens it will temporarily slow the reporting of new identified cases, falsely making it look as though the spread is slowing. This could happen before or after the end of August and could happen repeatedly, as it already has. Additionally, massive uncontrolled outbreaks could give the federal government shallow surface justification to attempt a major executive power grab prior to the upcoming election, such as postponing elections, and it could be in the executive branch's self interest to maximize the chances of making this happen

Now that mask wearing is being sanctioned by Trump and by Republican governors the reinfection rate should begin to decrease.  But there are 14 states for which Rt is between 0.98 and 1.02.  The number of states with Rt > 1.0  will probably bounce around for a while, until a clear trend emerges.  I'm staying below the crowd for now.
Adjusting downward as some states are starting to drop just below 1.0.
Just adjusting for states turning corners.
43 states are so far > 1 ; as the cases increases, certain states may take actions but will not fully return to a complete lockdown as we have damaged considerably the economy.

Today 9 states below 1.0 (would be enough for bin 4), 10 more below 1.4 (all those going down below 1.0 would be enough for bin 3).. Median down to 1.06 (all from 1.06 going down below 1.0 would be enough for bin 1). 33 states below 1.10.
Looks like daily cases in the US could have plateaued by now or be at least close to it. 40 days to go - which is an eternity with Covid-19 (Rt looked completely (!) different 2 months ago than it does now). All bins still possible.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.

Arizona just slipped below, currently at 7 under. New Hampshire, Connecticut, and DC trending up.

Currently only six states have an Rt of less than 1.0. Those states have been conservative in their reopening. State policies regarding reopening of businesses, and more importantly schools, do and will continue to affect Rt. Making the economy the priority, and not carefully considering health related factors which will dictate not only the health of citizenry but also the health of the economy, is a fool's errand that many continue to pursue.

Even further away from the crowd...
Today 8 states below 1.0. Median down to 1.07 (was 1.12 8 days ago). 30 states below 1.10.
This looks to be a stabilizing rate. The spike should move downward as we get closer to election time as people become used to limiting contact and states close or limit areas of congregation.
Its a hard test. NY has had zero deaths for a few days and we're still not under 1

Many of the states lack either the will or the resources or the infrastructure required to control their outbreaks. Some of the states that currently have an Rt of less than one will most likely experience spillover from “high risk” neighboring states. The question is will they be able to control those outbreaks? Will their citizens continue to implement public health measures?
Today only 7 below 1.0. Median down to 1.09 (where it was 2 weeks ago before that huge peak). A little better than a month ago, when numbers started to rise again.
Too many states are too far out to rein it back in and too many citizens are unwilling to lock down or follow strict guidelines.
current rate of 1 is in 43 states - assuming some will get the spread under control in the next 45 days but not many
The numbers dipped below 1 during the lock down period in April/May. Since then they started creeping back up. School opening, resistance to masks are going to push these numbers way higher.

It's time to reassess;  I've been much too optimistic.  But I'm still not putting any chips on "43 or more," which implies there will not be 9 states with Rt < 1.0.  I believe there will be 15-20 such states. I find the challenges where I differ significantly from the crowd to be the most interesting.  There is risk involved, and a bad forecast can really hurt your score.  But no risk equals no reward, ... should be interesting.

Only 7 today (would be bin 5). 15 more below 1.10 (if they all turned below 1.0, it would be bin 2), median 1.11 (if all including median and below turned below 1.0, it would be bin 1), all states except for 2 below 1.30.
48 days to go. General trend of new cases looks like it could be flattening. All bins still possible, but I´m slightly shifting weight to the lower ones. Against the crowd and some of the best here...

People are likely to go out during summer months and most states are unlikely to go back to complete lockdown. At present 43 states have an Rt >/= 1.0. Even during the lockdown phase, only a few states managed to get the Rt <1. It seems to be unlikely that more than 7 states would be able to do so during the summer with less aggressive strategies.
I'm not betting that the virus will go away by August 31.  I'm betting that the curve will bend down by then.

As of right now, all but 7 states have Rt levels of 1 or higher (https://rt.live/).  The trend over the last few months has been for it to worsen... but there seems to be a disparity between those states that engage in good practices and those that don't.  So there might be a hard floor of around 43.  So the question becomes, will that improve or degrade in the next month and a half in those 43?   The re-openings of Florida and Texas are warnings to other states that CV is still virulent.  But the nature of the virus hasn't changed, and we see little evidence that the American temperament and attitude towards the virus is changing much.   The habits which have contributed to the spread generally continue.

Now at 44 states above 1.0, with both Arkansas and North Carolina knocking on the door at 0.99 and rising. Updated July 12: I’ve been thinking a lot about this question, because it really gets to the heart of what Americans will and will not do to protect each other. To get Rt below 1, you need the right barriers in place. Masks are a good barrier, but they are not foolproof, and I’m afraid an over reliance on them will fail at reducing the spread to a manageable level. Masks work. Social distancing works. Keeping people from congregating inside works. You really need all three, though, to have the type of impact that is now needed. There’s too much virus in our communities right now for us to realistically say that if we simply wear masks, we can reopen theaters and bars and schools. Our federal and state governments have failed us, and we’ve failed each other, by politicizing the only practical steps we should be taking to allow at least a limited social and economic recovery. I’m afraid we’re basically screwed until a working vaccine is available for the masses, or until we attain herd immunity the hard way (and we’re maybe only 10% of the way there). Sorry to be such a Debbie Downer, but I’m not really optimistic for the good ol’ USA over the near term. On August 19, 2016, Donald Trump asked the rhetorical question, “What have you got to lose?” Well, now we have a solid answer. We’ve made America great in a way few would’ve imagined 4 years ago.

We are now at 43 states over 1.0, with 3 more at 0.97 or higher and increasing. As some states throttle back on reopening plans, there may be some reduction, but with no nationwide strategy in place, I don’t see more than a handful of states dropping below 1.0 by August 31. Allocating 81% between buckets 4 & 5.

For me, the easiest way to explain my risk assessment is to look at the existing trends. The R naught is not something that is widely tracked (compared to new cases or deaths in absolute numbers). But given the existing state of 38 states higher than 1, layered against (i) rising case numbers nationally and rising hospitalizations says the virus is still spreading, (ii) despite the rising case numbers, states are trending towards reopening. Pause orders are not effective because it simply maintains the status quo- which in a rising COVID environment, does nothing to reduce the R naught, absent any additional countermeasures and (iii) mask orders are not yet widely in place with states with the biggest spread. If we are not staying home, increased mask use is the only thing we can layer on to effectively bring the R naught down. There is good science behind it (I'm not debating whether the mask protects the user or the people around them- it is simply true that there is a strong correlation between increased mask use and reduction of any infectious spread). Even a mandate at this point may not work given the politization of use. Now back to the buckets. 24 of fewer is a zero possibility. In 6 weeks it is impossible to imagine 14 states with R naughts above 1 to bring down the spread. More infections are happening today which means numbers for the next 3-4 weeks will only go up. Immediate action will only bring the numbers down in 4-6 weeks. And that depends on widespread adoption (of masks) because there are no other countermeasures available. Then I just looked at the remaining buckets to rank them among each other. Given the trends, I think it's likely that more states will experience increased spread. But that the same time, states are trying to limit spread as much as possible so, hopefully it won't be rampant. So I placed the greatest weight to 2 buckets- making sure to allocate more than 50% because that is what I think is the likely scenario. Then I just allocated between the two, again on a relative basis. I think it is more likely that with the summer and the continued to desire to re-open until it becomes painfully obvious that we cant, that the number of states with an increased R naught will grow. Lastly, weighing the trend today against the remaining 2 buckets, I allocated the remainder on a relative basis.
43 states are so far > 1 ; as the cases increases, certain states may take actions but will not fully return to a complete lockdown as we have damaged considerably the economy.
Only 8 below 1 today. Median 1.12, maximum 1.34. 53 days to go, trend new cases down.

It does not look like any of the states, with a few exceptions, are thinking of reversing the reopening of economy. There will be protests and upheavals thorough the summer, and the current administration will do everything it can to normalize the death count.

As @Bobbiekar52 pointed out, once the reinfection rate is brought down around one, government officials seem to get complacent.  It's the accepted new normal.  So I'm reducing my admittedly extreme forecast to allow for some higher numbers.  I'm still below the crowd, just not as much.

US government response is so woeful that only a few states with rural populations will control infection rate.  All with large urban populations will show reproduction number (Rt) easily more than 1.0.  Lack of use of masks in public will also help increase reproduction number.

I am moving slightly upward.  States seem to be comfortable with an RT rate near 1 without necessarily going under 1. EG Missouri with a 1.09 continues to reopen with youth sports, and state fair planned in August.  No one wants to over respond this time around, as long as the current numbers aren’t too high, they will accept them.  With travel over the holiday, those states currently Barely under will see the number creep up.  A good example would be Virginia Beach, with huge tourist movement over the weekend.

By the end of the Summer, either many of the states currently with R>1 will have started to get their outbreaks under control again through reinstituting measures to do so (closing certain types of businesses, limiting gatherings, requiring masks, etc.), or they will have hit such high levels of infection that people take significant evasive action themselves, or they hit something approaching "herd immunity" (even if only temporarily). The states that are well below 1 right now generally have put measures in place (such as robust testing/tracing & mandatory indoor masking) that they should be able to keep infections low and R at or below 1, so long as they are not overwhelmed by travel-related cases.
If the infection rate peaks in August, and then declines, the reproduction number will also peak and then decline.  So I'm going to bet strongly against the crowd on this one.  No guts no glory!
As states reopen, it's going to be at slightly higher than 1 everywhere

Staying positive for now.  Still, two months to go. We'll see if the necessary measures will be implemented in the coming weeks.
From my perspective, the most likely outcome is a slight reduction in the number of states with higher than 1.0 Rt.
